Symptoms: Corneal ulceration
Treatment:
What are the treatment options for pterygium? 
Treatment aims to minimize external stimuli and actively treat chronic inflammation of the eye. 
1. Antibiotic eye drops are used to control conjunctival inflammation and alleviate congestion. Corticosteroid eye drops may be added when congestion is severe. To reduce external irritation, appropriate photochromic glasses can be worn. For inflammatory stimuli, 0.25% chloramphenicol and 0.5% prednisolone eye drops can be applied, with tetracycline and prednisolone eye ointment at night. 
2. Small, static pterygia do not require treatment. If the pterygium is progressive or has approached the pupillary area affecting vision or limiting eye movement, surgical removal may be considered. For patients unwilling to undergo surgery, 0.3ml of 2000-3000U/ml bleomycin solution can be injected into the neck and body of the pterygium under topical anesthesia, once a week, for 3-6 weeks as a course of treatment. To alleviate local reactions, 0.3ml of triamcinolone and tetracycline prednisolone ointment can be injected into the opposite conjunctiva and wrapped. 
3. Cryotherapy involves using a -40°C probe to contact the head and neck of the pterygium, destroying its neovascularization and causing it to shrink. This is used for smaller and thinner pterygia. 
4. Surgical options should aim to safely excise the pterygium entirely, ensure good optical results, and prevent recurrence. Techniques include head transposition, scleral exposure, conjunctival grafting, and advancements such as oral mucosa and amniotic membrane transplantation. Postoperative care should: ensure a flat, evenly positioned graft; use an iris repositor to remove subconjunctival hemorrhage; excise the pterygium thoroughly to maintain a smooth corneal surface while sparing healthy tissue; avoid damaging the tear ridge and tendons to prevent future adhesions or motility issues; remove more conjunctival sub-tissue beneath the pterygium to reduce rapid vascular or tissue proliferation post-surgery; thoroughly remove the corneal edge, sclera, and degenerative tissue on the cornea to prevent fibrovascular invasion. Additionally, supervise regular follow-ups to monitor for recurrence. 
5. Despite improvements in surgical techniques, pterygium recurrence is still a concern, with rates reported by Castroviejo between 25% and 45%. Proper postoperative adjuvant therapy can significantly reduce recurrence rates. These include: 
-Thiotepa, an anticancer drug, applied as an eye drop starting five days post-surgery, every three hours for eight weeks, which may continue for 3-6 months. It inhibits neovascular cell proliferation, preventing nuclear filamentous division. 
-Mitomycin C eye drops, an antiproliferative drug, applied postoperatively 3 times/d for 7 days or 2 times/d for 5 days, maintaining a low recurrence rate and safety. 
-Local corticosteroids post-surgery can inhibit inflammation and corneal edema, thereby preventing neovascularization. Prednisolone 0.5% eye drops or dexamethasone 0.025% eye drops, applied 4 times/d for 6 weeks, are suggested. 
6. Physical therapy options such as β-ray irradiation postoperatively have shown effectiveness in preventing recurrence, with the most commonly used being 90Srβ radiation. The total dose is 2600R, divided into three sessions post-surgery, reducing recurrence to 3.6%. High doses above 1.29C/kg (5000R) may increase the risk of radiation-induced cataracts. 
-Laser treatment using argon laser to photocoagulate the blood vessels in the neck and body of the pterygium can be followed by application of 0.5% prednisolone or 0.1% dexamethasone eye drops. 
Prognosis: Surgery is generally successful with good recovery. Postoperative recurrence is related to the characteristics of the pterygium (such as thickness and congestion), surgical technique, and incorrect operations. Continued exposure to risk factors also plays a significant role.

Symptoms: Emaciation, abdominal pain, constipation, fatigue
Treatment:
Treatment options for Inguinal Hernia include: 
Surgical treatment is recommended for all cases. The key points of the surgery involve first liberating and repositioning the herniated organs, then reconstructing a complete hernia sac before performing a high ligation and hernia repair. 
1. Hernia sac formation and high ligation 
(a) Bevan method: Commonly used for smaller sliding hernias, such as when the cecum has herniated. The procedure starts with an incision of the hernia sac followed by a semicircular incision of the peritoneum 2cm away from the edge of the cecum. The incision ends must reach the neck of the hernia sac, ensuring a complete hernia sac can be formed for high ligation. The cecum is meticulously liberated to the level of the internal ring, being careful not to damage the mesenteric and spermatic cord vessels. The herniated cecum is then repositioned, and the peritoneal semicircular incision ends are brought together and sutured longitudinally, forming a complete hernia sac for high ligation (Figure 1). 
(b) La Roque method: Suitable for larger sliding hernias, such as for herniated sigmoid colon. The front wall of the hernia sac is incised, and the intestine is freed towards the back side up to the internal ring, being cautious not to harm its mesenteric vessels. The abdominal oblique and transverse muscles are separated in the direction of the muscle fibers above the internal ring by 3cm, carefully avoiding damage to the iliohypogastric nerve. The peritoneum is then incised, and the freed herniated intestine is repositioned through the internal ring. 
(c) Ponka method: Suitable for larger sliding hernias. The procedure begins by separating the hernia sac along with the herniated intestine and spermatic cord to the deep side of the internal ring, ensuring not to injure the intestinal mesentery and spermatic vessels. The front wall of the hernia sac is incised, and cuts along both sides of the intestine extend to the deep side of the internal ring. The two cut edges are then sutured behind the liberated side of the intestine to form a complete internal ring, followed by repositioning of the intestine, and performing high ligation of the hernia sac (Figure 3), without the need for peritonealization of the posteriorly freed surface of the intestine. 
2. Hernia repair: Due to the characteristics of a sliding hernia, where the hernia ring is dilated and the strength of the abdominal wall's tendinous layers and transversalis fascia is severely compromised, repair of the internal ring often involves the Bassini method or the use of a mesh patch.

Symptoms: Pain in the liver area, chest pain, abdominal pain, abdominal distension, diarrhea, hepatomegaly, nausea and vomiting, splenomegaly, anemia, febrile infection, urticaria-like rash, high fever
Treatment:
What are the treatment options for clonorchiasis? 
(1) Treatment 
1. Bithionol is a commonly used medication for this disease, with a dosage of 40-60mg/d, taken orally three times a day every other day. A treatment course lasts for 10-15 days, with a 5-7 day gap before starting the next course. Improvement is generally seen from the third day of medication, with body temperature returning to normal within 3-6 days and clinical symptoms, including the swelling of the liver, gradually reducing. 
2. Praziquantel with a dosage of 60mg/(kg·d), taken consecutively for 3 days. The advantage of this medication is its good patient tolerance and short treatment duration. However, some believe its effectiveness is not significant, and in some cases, ineffective. Studies by Mao Xiaoxing and others (1993) using scanning electron microscopy have shown that praziquantel can cause damage to the tegument of the liver fluke, suggesting that increasing the dosage and extending the treatment duration might improve clinical outcomes, albeit further research is needed. 
3. Triclabendazole with a dosage of 10mg/kg body weight, taken as a single dose. This medication was used in veterinary medicine in 1983, first applied to humans in 1989, and recommended by the WHO in 1997. It has been widely used in Egypt, with no reports of its application in China thus far. In addition to treating the pathogen, clonorchiasis treatment should also incorporate other methods, such as selecting sensitive antibiotics to treat concurrent bacterial infections and surgical treatment for obstructive jaundice. 
(2) Prognosis 
Generally good. In the acute phase, extensive hepatic bleeding caused by the mass migration of juvenile worms can lead to death due to misdiagnosis and untimely treatment. Chronic cases may worsen due to concurrent bacterial cholangitis.

Symptoms: High fever with chills, cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, aversion to cold, chills, fever, fatigue, lymphatic rupture, pneumothorax, chest deformity, and sputum production
Treatment:
What are the treatment methods for Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia? 
1. Etiological Treatment 
(1) Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is effective against both the adult worms and microfilariae of filariae with better efficacy for Brugian filariasis than Bancroftian filariasis, though the adverse effects are more pronounced for the former. After oral administration, DEC is rapidly absorbed in the intestines and metabolized in the body, with almost all excreted through urine. The trace of DEC is hardly found in the blood 48 days after a single dose. The long-term therapeutic effect is better than the short-term outcome. The drug itself has mild adverse reactions, with high doses occasionally causing nausea, vomiting, dizziness, insomnia, etc. Due to the extensive killing of adult worms and microfilariae during treatment, patients may experience aversion to cold with high fever, headache, muscle pain throughout the body, rash, or even laryngeal edema, among other allergic reactions. Less commonly, there may be pain due to enlarged liver and spleen, hematuria, and proteinuria. Allergic reactions typically occur 6-8 hours after medication, and can be treated or mitigated with antihistamines, aspirin, corticosteroids, and other drugs. 
(2) Levamisole shows immediate efficacy against both B. malayi and W. bancrofti infections, but its long-term efficacy is inferior. Combination therapy with DEC can enhance the effect. Its adverse effects are more significant than those of DEC, mainly including fever, headache, muscle soreness in limbs, and fatigue. Fever usually does not exceed 39°C and lasts 2-3 days, disappearing after the discontinuation of the drug. 
(3) Flubendazole, synthesized in China in 1979, shows significant lethality against adult worms and microfilariae of Bancroftian filariasis. Its adverse reactions are similar to those of DEC. 
(4) A single dose of DEC or a combination of a single dose of DEC with a single dose of Ivermectin has been shown to be effective in treating filariasis, with the combination therapy proving to be more effective. 
2. Symptomatic Treatment 
Early allergic reactions manifesting as fever, cough, and asthma can be treated with antihistamines such as chlorpheniramine (Chlor-Trimeton), loratadine, or cetirizine (Zyrtec), and corticosteroids. Pleural effusion leading to chest tightness and dyspnea should be treated with thoracentesis.

Symptoms: Ascites, hepatomegaly, jaundice, edema of the lower extremities, pigment abnormalities
Treatment: Treatment methods for Budd-Chiari Syndrome include: Medical treatment: (1) Supportive and symptomatic treatment: Supportive therapy can buy time and create conditions for a definitive diagnosis and surgical treatment. Diuretics are administered to patients with ascites. Esophageal varices hemorrhage and hepatic encephalopathy should be treated accordingly. (2) Anticoagulation and thrombolysis: Patients with BCS caused by thrombosis should receive timely thrombolytic and anticoagulation therapy. (3) Etiological treatment: For patients with a clear cause or inducer, it should be removed, such as antiparasitic treatment for parasitic infections. Early discontinuation of oral contraceptives causing BCS, while providing liver protection, diuresis, and symptomatic treatment. Secondary to polycythemia vera could be managed with venesection, radio-phosphorus or myelosuppressive drugs such as chlorambucil, cyclophosphamide, or hydroxyurea. For patients secondary to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, ingestion of large doses of alkaline drugs or intravenous infusion of dextrose can temporarily alleviate hemolysis. Corticosteroids can control the onset of hemoglobinuria, and testosterone propionate has a certain effect. Resection or embolization therapy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy are options for tumors causing BCS. For inflammatory bowel disease or collagen disease, corticosteroids can be used to control the activity of the disease. Surgical treatment: Since 1948, when the first successful splenorenal venous shunting for treating a case of Budd-Chiari Syndrome was reported by Blakemore, surgical treatments have shown promising outcomes compared to medical treatments. It is now generally recognized that relieving hepatic vein and/or inferior vena cava obstruction surgically is the most ideal treatment approach. The selection of surgical method should be based on the pathological type and the location, extent, and degree of the obstruction. Types of surgery include: (1) Portosystemic shunting: This reduces portal venous pressure and hepatic sinusoidal pressure, preventing further liver cell damage and even leading to normal or only mildly fibrotic liver functions. For patients with patent inferior vena cava and hepatic vein obstruction, common surgical options are side-to-side portocaval shunt, mesocaval shunt, and end-to-side splenorenal shunt; when significant liver congestion enlarges, making the exposition of the portal vein, especially the caudate lobe enlarged, changing the normal anatomical position of portal vein and inferior vena cava, and causing difficulty in side-to-side anastomosis, some scholars recommend the “H” shaped bridging shunt, using a transplanted vessel placed between the mesenteric vein and the inferior vena cava, performing end-to-side anastomoses with both the inferior vena cava and the 'surgical trunk' of the mesenteric vein. To avoid shunt thrombosis, the “H” shaped shunt has been modified to a “C” shaped shunt in some cases. (2) Membranectomy: For patients with membranous obstruction of inferior vena cava or short segment stenosis without hepatic vein obstruction, initial intervention might involve Seldinger technique with balloon catheter dilation and stent placement. Failed intervention, recurrence, or thrombosis beneath the septum may necessitate surgical excision of the obstructive membrane or lesion under direct vision. (3) Cavo-atrial shunt: This surgical option is considered for long segment inferior vena cava obstruction without hepatic vein obstruction or when local excision of membranous or short segmental obstruction is difficult. (4) Radical corrective surgery: Employed for localized obstruction, with fresh thrombus formation, when thrombolysis is ineffective, or in cases with obstructions 1～6cm in length (including thrombotic cases), or when obstruction at the hepatic vein outlet needs to be addressed, or in the presence of a foreign body, or in pediatric cases. The surgery involves opening the thorax through the right 6th rib, opening the diaphragm, establishing extracorporeal circulation (optional), excising the diseased segment under direct vision, and reconstructing vascular continuity with a graft or bridge. (5) Peritoneal-venous shunt: This surgery is effective for treating ascites but is deemed palliative as it does not reverse the pathophysiological changes caused by hepatic vein and/or inferior vena cava obstruction. It is considered when other surgical options are not feasible or have failed, and ascites become a prominent issue, to relieve patient suffering and prolong life. (6) Orthotopic liver transplantation: First used by Putnam and others in 1976 for treating BCS. Glenn reported a 5-year survival rate of 44.7% in 23 advanced stage patients treated with liver transplantation, with multiple thromboembolic complications being the main cause of death post-surgery. Campbell reported an 88% 3-year cumulative survival rate after surgery with long-term anticoagulation therapy. Orthotopic liver transplantation is mainly used for fulminant hepatic failure and late-stage cirrhosis. Postoperative complications and management: (1) Heart failure: A common postoperative complication. Sudden increase in the volume of blood returning to the heart after relieving hepatic vein and/or inferior vena cava obstruction can exacerbate the burden on an already compromised heart, leading to heart failure. To prevent heart failure, immediate cardiotonic and diuretic treatments, including digoxin 0.4mg and furosemide 10-40mg IV, are beneficial in reducing the occurrence of heart failure. (2) Ascites or chylous ascites: Pre-surgical inferior vena cava obstruction hampers return flow, causing plasma to leak into liver lymphatic interspaces under the condition of no egress for hepatic venous blood, leading to stubborn and difficult-to-resolve ascites. Some patients may develop chylous ascites due to the rupture of high-pressure lymphatic vessels. Intraoperatively, damage to dilated lymphatic vessels is more likely, resulting in chylous ascites. For chylous ascites, oral administration of octreotide may accelerate resolution, and large volume ascites can be drained through peritoneal tapping. Surgical exploration to ligate the ruptured lymphatic vessels may be necessary for some cases. Chylothorax can be effectively managed by draining the effusion as much as possible and injecting tetracycline or erythromycin plus procaine, which often yields good results. (3) Hemothorax: Minor hemothorax requires close observation. If bleeding is significant (more than 100ml/h), thoracotomy for hemostasis should be promptly conducted. If caused by anticoagulation treatment, relevant monitoring indicators should be closely watched, and anticoagulant medications and dosages adjusted timely. (4) Hepatic encephalopathy: Since the liver function in Budd-Chiari Syndrome cases is often better than in cirrhosis cases, the occurrence rate of hepatic encephalopathy post portosystemic shunt is not high (<15%), and many episodes can be prevented with dietary attention. Moderate to severe cases should be managed as hepatic encephalopathy. (5) Artificial vascular occlusion: If thrombosis formation is suspected, blood flow Doppler can be utilized to detect clotting at the site of the artificial vessel. When conditions allow, ultrasound, indirect mesenteric vein angiography, or direct puncture angiography of the artificial vessel can be performed to examine the patency of the artificial vessel. Postoperative anticoagulation therapy can prevent occlusion. (6) Pulmonary embolism: Treatment for pulmonary embolism may include thrombolytic agents (urokinase, streptokinase, r-tPA, etc.) for thrombolysis. Besides systemic intravenous administration, interventional local thrombolysis can also be considered. Extracorporeal circulation establishment for pulmonar artery thrombectomy is an option when conditions permit. (7) Others: Including mediastinal effusion, lung abscess, chylothorax, etc., are less common. Symptoms can be cured through symptomatic treatment if they occur.

Symptoms: Conjunctival hyperemia, tearing, red eyes, eyelid edema, burning sensation in eyes, itchy eyes, difficulty opening eyes, swelling
Treatment: What are the treatment methods for conjunctivitis? General care includes: (1) Conducting three-level nursing care according to eye diseases; (2) Providing psychological care by explaining the condition to the patient, alleviating fear, and encouraging treatment acceptance; (3) Focusing on preventive education and carrying out disinfection and isolation measures thoroughly. Since conjunctivitis is highly infectious, enhance health education; avoid rubbing eyes with hands, patients should not share towels or basins, items used by patients should be washed and thoroughly disinfected promptly, and eye drops must be for individual use. Special care includes: (1) If there is excessive secretion, conjunctival sac irrigation should be done by flipping the eyelid to rinse the conjunctival surface while manually moving the upper and lower lids to flush out secretions from the fornix; (2) For acute catarrhal conjunctivitis, hot compresses are contraindicated and should not be applied; (3) For gonococcal conjunctivitis, treatment should be prompt to attempt rescue, with frequent and timely administration of medication. If one eye is affected, the healthy eye should be protected with a transparent eye shield. Contaminated items should be thoroughly washed and disinfected, and dressings incinerated; (4) Patients with allergic conjunctivitis should wear tinted protective glasses during the season of onset to block sunlight and prevent irritation from sunlight and airborne dust and pollen, inquire about allergy history, and eliminate allergens.

Symptoms: Reddening of the skin, headache, bleeding
Treatment:
Treatment options for Polycythemia Vera include: 

Venesection: Venesection quickly reduces the blood volume to normal, alleviates symptoms, and decreases the chances of bleeding and thrombosis formation. Bloodletting of 200-400ml every 2-3 days until the red blood cell count is below 6.0×10¹²/L and the hematocrit is below 50%. A single venesection can maintain the therapeutic effect for more than one month. This method is straightforward and can be adopted first. Younger patients, without thrombotic complications, may be treated solely with phlebotomy. However, rebound increases in red blood cells and platelets may occur after bloodletting, and repeated venesection could exacerbate an iron deficiency. Caution is advised for elderly patients and those with cardiovascular diseases, with no more than 200-300ml removed at a time and potentially extended intervals between sessions. Cell separation allows the selective removal of a large volume of red blood cells but requires the supplementation of an equal volume of isotype plasma. During venesection, intravenous fluid replacement is also necessary to dilute the blood. 

Chemotherapy: 
(1) Hydroxyurea, a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor, effectively suppresses polycythemia vera without inducing leukemia. The daily dosage is between 15-20mg/kg. If white blood cell count is maintained at 3.5-5×10⁹/L, hydroxyurea can be used long-term intermittently. 
(2) Alkylating agents have an 80%-85% efficacy rate. Cyclophosphamide and chlormethine (mustine) work rapidly, while busulfan and melphalan have longer remission periods, with treatment effects lasting about six months. Melphalan has fewer side effects, particularly reducing the risk of thrombocytopenia, which is an advantage. Alkylating agents carry a lower risk of inducing leukemia compared to radioactive nucleotides. Dosage and method for alkylating agents include an initial dose of cyclophosphamide at 100-150 mg/day, and for busulfan, mustine, and melphalan at 4-6 mg/day. After remission, a maintenance dose of cyclophosphamide at 50 mg/day or busulfan at 2 mg/day or every other day after a 4-week break. 
(3) Podophyllotoxin derivative: China's reports suggest a dosage of 2-4mg added to 10% glucose solution for intravenous infusion once daily, continuously, or intermittently until the hematocrit and hemoglobin levels return to normal. The average time to achieve remission is 60 days, with a median remission period of over 18 months. 

Alpha-interferon therapy: Interferons have an inhibitory effect on cell proliferation and have been used in recent years for the treatment of this disease at a dose of 3 million U/m², three times a week, administered subcutaneously. After 3 months of treatment, the spleen size reduces, and the number of venesections decreases. The remission rate can reach 80%. 

Radioactive nucleotide therapy: The beta radiation from Phosphorus-32 (32P) inhibits nuclear division and reduces cell counts. The initial oral dose is between 11.1×10⁷ and 14.8×10⁷ Bq, with red blood cell counts starting to decline after about 6 weeks, and reaching near-normal levels in 3-4 months, thereby alleviating symptoms with an efficacy rate of 75%-80%. If there is no remission after 3 months, a second dosage may be administered. The average remission time is 2-3 years. There is a risk of transition to leukemia with 32P, which has led to a decrease in its use in recent years. The prognosis is generally poor, with many deaths due to venous thrombosis, severe bleeding, or progression to myelofibrosis and acute leukemia.

Symptoms: Red eye, conjunctival congestion, eyelid redness and swelling, eye itchiness, burning sensation in the eye, tearing, epiphora
Treatment:
What are the treatment options for conjunctivitis?
1. Topical Treatment
  (1) Irrigation of the conjunctival sac primarily serves for cleansing, commonly using normal saline, 2%–3% boric acid solution, or 1:5000–1:10000 mercuric chloride (or potassium permanganate) solution.
  (2) Do not cover the affected eye, as a lot of secretions are present during conjunctivitis. Covering the eye obstructs the discharge of secretions, accumulating them within the conjunctival sac; moreover, covering increases the temperature of the conjunctival sac, which favors bacterial proliferation, exacerbating the conjunctivitis.
  (3) Local medications involving antimicrobial or antiviral eye drops should be selected based on the etiological diagnosis. Commonly, 0.5%–1% silver nitrate is used; during application, the eyelid should be turned, and the eye solution dropped on the lid's conjunctiva. After dropping the eye solution, wait for a moment before rinsing with saline. Alternatively, a cotton swab can be dipped in a small amount of the medication and applied to the surface of the lid's conjunctiva, immediately rinsed with saline.
2. Systemic Treatment
  For severe cases of conjunctivitis, such as gonococcal conjunctivitis or trachoma, combined systemic medication is required.

Symptoms: Papules, itching, severe pain
Treatment:
There is no specific cure for Keratosis Pilaris. Treatments include: 

1. Systemic treatments involve avoiding sun exposure, oral administration of chloroquine (250 mg, twice daily), and potentially using vitamin A (50,000 to 100,000 IU, three times daily) or isotretinoin (0.5 to 1 mg/kg, twice daily). 

2. Topical treatments for less severe and smaller affected areas may include cryotherapy, electrocautery, or laser treatment. Topically applied keratolytics such as 10% salicylic acid ointment or 0.1% tretinoin cream can also be used. 

3. Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) recommends nourishing the blood and moisturizing the skin with preparations such as Runfu Wan, Wenjing Tang, or Cangzhu Gao. 

Prognosis: Keratosis Pilaris typically begins to appear between the ages of 30 and 40 and may develop slowly over several years. Excessive exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light, similar to treatments used in psoriasis patients, can exacerbate or prolong the condition of Disseminated Superficial Actinic Porokeratosis (DSAP). It may start in infancy or childhood. The genetic traits have not been clearly defined. It can occur alongside other clinical types. Reports of worsening conditions exist.

Symptoms: Abdominal pain, chest pain, rusty sputum, cough with sputum, fever, diarrhea, cough, abnormal breathing, rales, nausea and vomiting, 'rotten peach' blood sputum
Treatment:
Treatment options for Paragonimiasis include:
  1. Symptomatic treatment focuses on the care of patients with hemoptysis and those with cerebral and spinal forms, administering the appropriate medication for symptomatic relief.
  2. Antiparasitic treatment:
     (1) Praziquantel: Provides effective treatment for this condition. The total dosage of 120–150mg/kg is divided into 2-3 doses consumed within 2 days, showing significant therapeutic effects. Patients with cerebral involvement should receive two treatment courses, with a one-week interval. Side effects are mild and disappear after discontinuation of the drug.
     (2) Bithionol: Administered at 1.5–3.0g, or 40–50mg/kg per day, divided into three doses, taken daily or every other day. For pulmonary type, the treatment course lasts 10–15 days; the cerebral type may require 2-3 repeated courses. Calcified, atrophic, and inactive lesions are irresponsive. Pre-treatment with anthelmintic drugs may be required for intestinal parasites. Side effects include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritation of the mouth or anus, but disappear after discontinuation. During antiparasitic treatment, some cases may experience a heterologous protein reaction, manifesting as urticaria; severe cases may lead to anaphylactic shock or laryngeal edema, for which corticosteroids are indicated, and medication is temporarily discontinued. It is contraindicated in pregnant women and individuals with severe heart, liver, or kidney diseases.
  3. Surgical intervention: Effective for cerebral and spinal forms of paragonimiasis with compression symptoms. However, surgery may not be effective for atrophic lesions; abdominal and nodular forms might require surgery if necessary.

Symptoms: Head relatively larger, facial appearance resembles an 'old man', alert reactions, emaciation, varying degrees of malnutrition, subcutaneous fat deficiency in limbs, loose skin, excessive wrinkling, easy desquamation. Cranial sutures may be widened or overlapping, larger anterior fontanelle, fingernails and toenails.
Fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, pale stool, joint pain, jaundice
Treatment:
What are the treatment methods for Hepatitis C? 
The necessity for Hepatitis C treatment varies as the Hepatitis C virus manifests across six genotypes, each responding differently to treatments. Thorough screening is essential before commencing any treatment to identify the most suitable treatment plan. 
Historically, combination therapy with interferon and ribavirin has been the principal treatment for Hepatitis C. However, interferon is not universally accessible and often not well tolerated, with some genotypes responding better to interferon than others. Moreover, a significant number of patients treated with interferon do not complete their treatment course. Consequently, while Hepatitis C is generally considered curable, many fail to achieve a cure. 
Scientific advancements have led to the development of new antiviral drugs for Hepatitis C, which may be more effective and better tolerated than existing treatments. Recently, new drugs such as telaprevir and boceprevir have been approved in some countries. Extensive efforts are needed to ensure that, with these advancements, therapy becomes accessible to more infected individuals worldwide.

Symptoms: Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, hyperprolactinemia, female infertility, myxedema, lobular hyperplasia of mammary glands, oligomenorrhea, menstrual disorders, anovulation, ovarian dysfunction, estrogen deficiency, abnormal sweating
Treatment:
Treatment options for Galactorrhea-Amenorrhea Syndrome include: 
1. Etiological treatment, which encompasses: 
   (a) Withdrawal from causative medications (including oral contraceptives) generally leads to natural recovery. If menstruation does not resume six months post-withdrawal, pharmacological treatment may be used. 
   (b) Primary hypothyroidism is treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy. Avoid using bromocriptine solely based on galactorrhea or amenorrhea symptoms, as it can exacerbate the condition by inhibiting TSH secretion through hypothalamic suppression. 
   (c) For patients with intracranial tumors, surgical removal or radiation therapy is administered as per the condition. Clinical observations suggest that pharmacological treatment alone is superior to surgery or radiation for prolactinoma patients with infertility, as it's less invasive and aids in the recovery of the gonadal axis. Nonetheless, surgery is recommended for patients with macroadenomas presenting with compression symptoms, ineffective bromocriptine treatment, or non-secreting pituitary adenomas with decreased D2 receptors. Bromocriptine treatment before and after surgery can enhance its effectiveness. 
2. Pharmacological treatment includes: 
   (a) Bromocriptine, a semi-synthetic ergoline derivative and a dopamine receptor agonist, inhibits prolactin synthesis and secretion, and directly affects the pituitary tumor and PRL cells, suppressing tumor growth and secretion of PRL, GH, TSH, and ACTH. It is the preferred treatment for various types of hyperprolactinemia and especially in young patients wishing to conceive. 
   (b) Levodopa metabolizes into dopamine in the body, releasing PIF and reducing prolactin levels while increasing gonadotropin levels. 
   (c) Cabergoline (CV205-502), a non-ergoline dopamine agonist, targets the same indications as bromocriptine and is especially suitable for patients who cannot tolerate bromocriptine, or when treatment is ineffective or relapse occurs. 
   (d) Vitamin B6 increases the conversion rate of dopamine in the hypothalamus, thereby enhancing the effect of PIF. 
3. Ovulation induction therapy is employed when bromocriptine alone fails to induce ovulation and pregnancy. 
4. Surgical and radiation therapy are considered when pharmacological treatment is ineffective, when tumors cause significant compression symptoms, or when concurrent hormone-secreting tumors are present.

Symptoms: Muscle soreness, fever with abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, convulsions, abdominal pain
Treatment:
The treatment of Campylobacter Enteritis includes two main approaches: general measures and specific antimicrobial therapy. 

General measures involve gastrointestinal isolation. The patient's feces must be thoroughly disinfected, with the isolation period lasting from the onset of illness until fecal cultures turn negative. For patients experiencing significant fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, symptomatic treatment is provided along with bed rest. A diet of easily digestible semi-liquid foods is recommended, and fluid replenishment may be necessary when needed. 

For antimicrobial therapy, the bacterium is sensitive to gentamicin, erythromycin, chloramphenicol, streptomycin, kanamycin, neomycin, tetracyclines, and clindamycin, while it exhibits resistance to penicillin and cephalosporins. The choice of antibiotic can be based on clinical conditions. Erythromycin is a choice for enteritis, administered orally at 0.8-1.2g/day for adults and 40-50mg/kg/day for children, over a course of 2-3 days. Quinolone antibiotics, such as ofloxacin, also yield good efficacy but may affect bone development in young children. For bacterial endocarditis, gentamicin is preferred; for meningitis, chloramphenicol is the first choice. For severe infections, the treatment course should be extended to 3-4 weeks to prevent relapse.

Symptoms: Inflammatory cell infiltration, pale and swollen tongue, root of the tongue abscess, white patches, erosion, pain
Treatment:
Treatment options for Oral Leukoplakia include:

1. For epithelial simple hyperplasia or simple white keratosis, all local irritating factors should be eliminated, and smokers should quit smoking.

2. White patches suspected of malignant transformation, such as verrucous, granular, and erosive lesions, should be surgically removed, treated with cryotherapy or CO2 laser therapy. Patients who have been treated should be periodically followed up to promptly detect and treat any recurrence.

3. The application of 0.3% tretinoin cream locally for one to several weeks can lead to the regression of leukoplakia. Tretinoin inhibits epidermal keratinization. After the lesion regresses and treatment is stopped, recurrence may occur, but reapplication of tretinoin remains effective.

4. Vitamin A and Vitamin E. Vitamin A helps maintain the integrity and health of epithelial tissue structure and is considered by some to have significance in preventing epithelial malignancy. Vitamin E has a beneficial effect on metabolism and strong antioxidant properties, preventing the oxidation of Vitamin A and facilitating its absorption. Vitamin A is taken orally at a dose of 250,000 IU three times a day. Vitamin E is taken at a dose of 50mg three times a day.

Symptoms: Opacity, thickening, uneven surface, brittleness, nail stratification, discoloration, nail plate lifting, nail plate atrophy, nail plate detachment, hook nail, and paronychia
Treatment: The treatment methods for onychomycosis include: 1) General management: Avoid scratching the skin lesions on other body parts with hands. Keep fingers and toes clean to prevent infection. Improve diet and lifestyle, and pay attention to mental health management. 2) Treat concurrent tinea infections aggressively. 3) Antifungal therapy, specifically the use of drugs such as ciclopirox. 4) Surgical treatment: Removal of the affected nail(s), in conjunction with topical antifungal therapy.

Symptoms: Hemoptysis, bronchial hemorrhage, hematemesis and melena, hematuria, epistaxis
Treatment: The treatment principles for DIC are sequential, timely, individualized, and dynamic. Main treatments include management of the underlying disease and removal of inducing factors, anticoagulation therapy, replacement of coagulation factors, antifibrinolytic therapy, thrombolytic treatment, and symptomatic management. Aside from symptomatic treatment, it is often advocated to concurrently proceed with other treatments as deemed necessary. However, recent years have seen a tendency towards sequential treatment, meaning that various therapies are carried out one after another in the order mentioned above, proceeding to the next only if the current treatment does not achieve satisfactory results. 1. Management of the underlying disease and removal of inducing factors such as controlling infections, treating tumors, handling obstetric diseases and traumas, correcting shock, hypoxia, and acidosis, etc. 2. Anticoagulation therapy remains to be a crucial measure to halt the pathological process of DIC, alleviate organ damage, and restore the balance between coagulation and anticoagulation. (1) Heparin Therapy: Indications for heparin therapy include, but are not limited to, incompatible blood transfusions, amniotic fluid embolism, acute leukemia or other tumors, septic abortion, fulminant purpura, heat stroke, underlying hypercoagulable states like eclampsia, nephrotic syndrome, cardiopulmonary diseases, diabetes, etc., subacute or chronic DIC, early stages of acute DIC, among others. Usage of heparin still remains controversial in cases such as infectious DIC, severe hepatic DIC, and neonatal DIC. Contraindications include patients with recent surgeries or wounds without proper hemostasis, recent severe hemoptysis from tuberculosis, active peptic ulcers with significant bleeding, DIC induced by snake venom, and late-stage patients with multiple coagulation factor deficiencies and significant fibrinolysis. The dose of heparin has been emphasized on 'adequate dosage'. In acute DIC, conventional heparin (sodium heparin) could be used ranging from 45,000 to 90,000 U/day. Recent understanding of heparin's action and the improvement of formulations have led to a trend of using smaller dosages to reduce or mitigate bleeding complications. The regular heparin dosage for acute DIC ranges from 15,000 to 45,000 U/day, typically around 15,000 U/day, without exceeding 7,500 U every 6 hours, and can be continued for 3-5 days according to the clinical situation. Low-molecular-weight heparin (e.g., Tinzaparin, Innohep) compared to regular heparin, has higher bioavailability, stronger anti-factor Xa activity, weaker antithrombin activity, less dependence on AT-III, less likely to induce thrombocytopenia, and has slower anticoagulation effects with fewer bleeding complications. It is widely used with a common dose of 75-150 U/(kg·d) for 5 consecutive days. Observations by Japanese scholars suggest a 75 U/(kg·d) dose to be more safe and effective. Conventionally, heparin was administered via continuous intravenous infusion to maintain a steady and safe plasma anticoagulation concentration. Recently, subcutaneous injections every 6 hours have been advocated. Low-molecular-weight heparin is also administered subcutaneously every 6 hours based on clinical conditions for a continuous period of 3-5 days. (2) Other anticoagulants and antiplatelet drugs: Salvia miltiorrhiza (Danshen) or compound Danshen injection has been shown through experimental and clinical studies to possess certain anticoagulant and antiplatelet effects, and has been used in DIC treatment with confirmed efficacy, safety, without the need for strict hematological monitoring, and with no notable adverse reactions. It can be used in conjunction with heparin to reduce the latter's dosage or as the primary anticoagulant in chronic DIC, suspected cases, or when confirmatory diagnostic and hematological monitoring facilities are not available. The recommended dose is 20-40 mL of compound Danshen injection added to 100-200 mL of 5% glucose injection solution for rapid intravenous infusion, 2-4 times/day, for a continuous period of 3-5 days. Dextran 40 glucose injection has antiplatelet, volume supplementation, and microcirculation improvement effects; it has certain auxiliary therapeutic value for DIC with a common dosage of 500 mL per time for intravenous drip, not exceeding 1000 mL per day, and can be continued for 3-5 days. Dipyridamole inhibits platelet aggregation by inhibiting the metabolism of cAMP within platelets, thus possessing certain anti-thrombotic effects. The usual dosage is 200-500 mg placed in 100-200 mL of infusion solution for intravenous drip, 2-3 times/day, with a slow drip rate to avoid local vascular irritation. Antithrombin III (AT-III): Recent studies have indicated consumptive reduction of AT-III levels in approximately 80% of acute DIC patients. This can not only lower the body's anticoagulant activity, accelerating and exacerbating the DIC pathological process but also result in poor heparin treatment outcomes and an increase in bleeding complications. Timely and appropriate supplementation of AT-III is hence one of the key measures in DIC treatment. When no AT-III preparations are available, whole blood or plasma with AT-III 1U or 2U per mL respectively can be used. Aspirin exerts antiplatelet effects by inhibiting prostaglandin metabolism, mainly used in chronic or subacute DIC, with a dosage of 50-250 mg, 2-3 times/day, which can be continued for 5-10 days or longer. Ticlopidine is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits platelet aggregation by stabilizing platelet membranes and suppressing ADP-induced platelet aggregation. It has been used clinically for the prevention and treatment of cerebral thrombosis. Given the important role of platelet activation in DIC, this drug can be utilized in the treatment of acute and chronic DIC, with a dosage of 250 mg, twice/day, for a total of 5-7 days. Its main side effect is a tendency towards bleeding. Other traditional Chinese medicines: Domestic literature reports that Chuanxiong, Panax notoginseng, Carthamus tinctorius (safflower), peach kernel, Andrographis paniculata, and several other Chinese herbal medicines with varying degrees of anticoagulant or antiplatelet effects, either used alone or in combination, have been applied as adjunctive treatments for DIC and have achieved relatively good results. Among them, Chuanxiong has a venous injection formulation, with a dosage of 20-30 mL, once or twice/day, which can be continued for more than a week. 3. Platelet and Coagulation Factor Supplementation Indications: (1) Patients have clear evidence of significant platelet or coagulation factor reduction. (2) The causative factors have been removed and anticoagulant treatment has been administered, but DIC has not been adequately controlled. (3) Some scholars believe that DIC patients, whose underlying diseases can be rapidly eliminated, such as pathological obstetrics and traumas, or those not suitable for anticoagulant treatment like heparin, can achieve effective DIC control through aggressive management of the primary disease and supplementation of platelets or coagulation factors. Main Preparations: (1) Fresh Whole Blood: Provides platelets and all coagulation factors except tissue factor. To rapidly correct the status of low platelets and coagulation factors in acute DIC, if the patient's cardiac function permits, a single blood transfusion of 800-1500 mL can be performed, or according to 20-30 mL/kg to increase platelet count to above 50×10^9/L and various coagulation factors to above 50%. To avoid triggering or exacerbating DIC by administrating platelets and coagulation factors, heparin 5-10 U per mL of blood (or other blood products) can be added during transfusion. Based on the author's over ten years of experience, this method can prevent DIC relapse without the risk of inducing bleeding complications. (2) Fresh Plasma: Except for red cells, everything is the same as in fresh whole blood, but the concentration of platelets, coagulation factors, etc., is approximately double. Plasma can reduce the total volume of liquid input for the patient, avoiding excessive cardiac load, and can also prevent the increase in blood viscosity and the unfavorable factors for DIC caused by a large influx of red cells and the release of membrane phospholipids due to red cell fragmentation. Some scholars have found that inputting 1000 mL of fresh plasma within 45 minutes can elevate the Factor VIII: C activity from 20% to 100% and fibrinogen to above 1.0 g/L, with the platelet count increasing to above 50×10^9/L. (3) Platelet Suspension: For DIC patients with platelet count lower than 20×10^9/L and suspected or severe cranial or visceral hemorrhage, emergency platelet suspension transfusion is required. Conventionally, the platelets separated from 500 mL of normal whole blood are termed as 1 U. The platelet transfusion dosage should aim to increase the patient's platelet count to above 50×10^9/L. To achieve this goal, platelet transfusion within 24 hours should not be less than 10 U, or according to 1 U per every 5 kg of body weight, or platelet 10 U/m² of body surface area. (4) Fibrinogen: For acute DIC patients with significant hypofibrinogenemia or severe bleeding, fibrinogen transfusion can be administered. The initial dosage is 2.0-4.0 g for intravenous drip, with subsequent dosages adjusted according to the clinical situation, aiming to raise plasma fibrinogen to above 1.0 g/L, with a total amount of 8.0-12.0 g within 24 hours. Since fibrinogen has a half-life of approximately 100 hours, in patients without significant fibrinolysis, additional use of this product is generally not required after 24 hours. (5) Factor VIII and Prothrombin Complex: Rarely required in DIC treatment practice, but occasionally indicated for severe liver disease and DIC patients. 4. Antifibrinolytic Agents Indications: According to modern views, these drugs should not be routinely used in DIC. Their main indications include: (1) DIC patients with clear clinical and experimental evidence of significant fibrinolysis, (2) Late-stage DIC, where secondary fibrinolysis has become the main cause of delayed bleeding. Main Preparations: (1) Aminocaproic Acid: 2.0-10.0 g/day, administered in divided doses for slow intravenous injection or infusion, use with caution in patients with shock. (2) Tranexamic Acid: 0.2-1.0 g/day, administered in divided doses for intravenous injection or infusion. (3) Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid: 0.5-2.0 g/day, administered in divided doses for intravenous injection or infusion. (4) Aprotinin: A broad-spectrum protease inhibitor, also inhibiting plasmin and Factor X activation, theoretically most suitable for DIC treatment due to its dual blockade of fibrinolysis and coagulation. The initial dose is 50,000 U, followed by a continuous intravenous drip of 10,000 U/h, or a total amount of 100,000-200,000 U/day, administered in divided doses for infusion. 5. Thrombolytic Therapy Indications: Due to secondary fibrinolysis being common in the mid to late stages of DIC, thrombolytic therapy is less frequently used, only in the following situations. (1) Prominent organ dysfunction that has not been effectively corrected by previous treatments. (2) End-stage DIC, where both coagulation and fibrinolysis processes have ceased, but organ function recovery is slow or poor. (3) Clear clinical and laboratory evidence of thromboembolism. Main Drugs: (1) Urokinase (UK): The commonly used dosage is an initial dose of 4000 U/kg for intravenous injection, followed by a continuous drip of 400 U/h. Due to its non-selective action, which can activate systemic fibrinolysis and degrade fibrinogen upon administration, this drug is currently less frequently used. In recent years, a single-chain urokinase has been developed abroad, whose activation of fibrinolysis relies on the presence of fibrin, showing stronger specificity, higher efficacy, and fewer adverse reactions. (2) Tissue Plasminogen Activator (t-PA): A highly efficient and specific plasminogen activator developed in recent years, possessing strong activation of plasminogen in the presence of fibrin. The commonly used dosage is 900,000-1,500,000 U, administered via intravenous injection within 30-60 minutes, or by continuous intravenous drip of 5000 U/(kg·h). (3) Anistreplase (APSAC): A new type of high-efficiency thrombolytic agent, lacking thrombolytic activity outside the body but, upon entering the bloodstream and binding with fibrin, undergoes deacylation hydrolysis, exposing the active center of plasminogen, activating thrombus plasminogen, and promoting fibrin degradation. Compared with streptokinase, urokinase, and recombinant t-PA, APSAC has a longer half-life, stronger affinity to fibrin, and fewer allergic reactions, making it an effective thrombolytic agent. There have been successful reports of its use in DIC thrombolytic therapy, with a dosage of 30 mg, administered via a Mofi tube drip, 2-3 times/day, for 3-5 consecutive days. 6. Other Treatment Measures (1) Corticosteroids: Not routinely recommended for DIC patients, but the following situations may warrant consideration: (1) Underlying diseases requiring corticosteroid treatment, such as various hypersensitivity diseases causing DIC, (2) Sepsis-induced shock complicated with DIC adopting strong anti-infection measures, (3) Concurrent adrenal cortex insufficiency. (2) Scopolamine: This drug can relieve vascular spasms, contributing to microcirculation improvement and shock correction. It can be pre-emptively used in the early and middle stages of DIC, with a dosage of 10-20 mg for intravenous injection or infusion, 2-3 times/day. 7. Efficacy Standards (1) Cure: (1) Underlying diseases and inducing factors have been removed or controlled, (2) DIC symptoms and signs have disappeared, (3) Laboratory indicators have returned to normal. (2) Improvement: Among the above 3 indicators, if 1 fails to meet the standard or 2 have not fully met the standard. (3) Ineffective: If the above indicators have not met the standard or the patient dies due to DIC. Prognosis According to statistics, the cure rate for DIC ranges from 50% to 80%, the improvement rate is 20% to 30%, and the mortality rate is 20% to 40%.

Symptoms: Maculopapular rash, papules, wheals, itching, generalized erythematous patches, skin pruritus, crusting, desquamation
Treatment: The treatment principles for Caterpillar Dermatitis focus on removing toxic hairs, relieving pain, reducing inflammation, and avoiding scratching. Topical treatments may include the application of traditional herbal plasters or adhesive tapes, and the use of clear tapes to adhere to the affected area to remove toxic hairs is recommended. Subsequently, a variety of anti-inflammatory and antipruritic agents can be applied, such as camphor, coal tar solution, freshly mashed Portulaca oleracea or Aloe vera (also known as dragon's tongue) mixed with realgar powder for external application. For severe itching, antihistamines may be administered. Oral intake of traditional Chinese medicine that clears heat and dampness can also be adjusted according to the patient's condition.

Symptoms: Muscle pain, difficulty opening eyes, weakness
Treatment: What are the treatment methods for Congenital Myotonia? Treatment options primarily include pharmacotherapy similar to that for congenital myotonia. Medications demonstrating positive responses include local anesthetics and antiarrhythmic drugs, which mainly inhibit sodium channels. Mexiletine is the drug of choice, administered at a dosage of 100–300 mg, three times daily. Quinidine sulfate at 0.3–0.6 g, procainamide (procainamide) at 250–500 mg, once daily, all show definitive therapeutic effects. Tocainide at 1200 mg/day is effective but not recommended due to its potential to cause agranulocytosis. Phenytoin at 100 mg, three times daily, is effective in some cases. As for the prognosis, the condition is mostly non-progressive, with the situation tending to stabilize or improve after reaching adulthood.

Symptoms: High fever, chills, cough, blood in sputum, chest pain
Treatment:
For pneumococcal pneumonia strains that are sensitive to penicillin, Penicillin G is the preferred medication. For non-severe cases, oral administration of Penicillin G or V 250~500mg every 6 hours is recommended. For uncomplicated pneumococcal pneumonia, aqueous Penicillin G 0.5~2 million units IV injection every 4~6 hours is advised. 
Approximately 25% of pneumococcal strains are resistant to penicillin. In the United States, the rate of relative or high resistance among clinically isolated strains is 15%~30%, which is higher in other parts of the world, especially Spain, Japan, Israel, South Africa, and Western Europe. Many penicillin-resistant strains also show resistance to other antibiotics. Agar plates containing 1μg of benzylpenicillin are suitable for detecting resistant strains. Isolates with inhibition zones ≤19mm should be further tested using broth dilution methods. For highly resistant strains, treatment should be based on in vitro susceptibility tests. High doses of penicillin, cefotaxime or ceftriaxone are effective against most resistant strains. New-generation quinolones (levofloxacin, sparfloxacin, gatifloxacin, and trovafloxacin) are commonly chosen for penicillin-resistant strains and can also be alternative options for treatment of strains sensitive to penicillin. Vancomycin, as the only drug with a sustained activity, has antibacterial activity against all pneumococcal strains and should be the drug of choice for severely ill patients, particularly in cases where there is a high incidence of resistance to penicillin. 
Other effective drugs include cephalosporins, erythromycin, and clindamycin. Tetracycline is less reliable for pneumococcal coverage and should not be used in patients with severe conditions. Oral medications include erythromycin or clindamycin 300mg every 6 hours. Parenteral alternatives include cefotaxime 1~2g IV injection every 6 hours; ceftriaxone 1~2g IV injection every 12 hours; ceftazidime 500mg IV injection every 8 hours; erythromycin 0.5~1g IV injection every 6 hours; or clindamycin 300~600mg IV injection every 6~8 hours. Besides cefotaxime and ceftriaxone, most third-generation cephalosporins have relatively no antibacterial activity against pneumococci. 
In cases of suspected meningitis, patients should be given cefotaxime 2g IV injection every 4~6 hours or ceftriaxone 1~2g IV injection every 12 hours, along with vancomycin 1g IV injection every 12 hours, with or without rifampin 600mg/d orally, until susceptibility results are known. For patients with empyema, treatment should include appropriate drainage in addition to antibiotics. 
Supportive care includes bed rest, fluid supplementation, and analgesics for pleuritic pain. Patients with cyanosis, significant hypoxemia, severe respiratory distress, circulatory disturbance, or delirium should be given oxygen therapy. Continuous blood gas monitoring is essential, especially in patients with chronic lung diseases. 
It is generally recommended that patients over the age of 35 undergo follow-up chest X-rays. Chest radiographs may not show resolution of infiltrates until several weeks later, especially in severe cases, those with bacteremia, or patients with pre-existing chronic lung conditions. Persistence of infiltrates after 6 weeks or more of treatment suggests the possibility of an underlying primary bronchogenic carcinoma or TB.

Symptoms: Milk secretion from the breasts outside of pregnancy or breastfeeding, menstrual irregularities
Treatment:
The treatment for prolactinoma depends on the size of the tumor, the level of increased prolactin (PRL), symptoms, and fertility desires. 
1. Medical treatment: The first choice is bromocriptine, starting with 1.25 mg at bedtime. The dose is increased by 1.25-2.5 mg every 2-3 days, with an effective daily dose being 5-7.5 mg. After treatment, blood PRL levels decrease, and menstruation resumes in 2-3 months. Medication can be discontinued after about a year to observe for recurrence, although the rate of recurrence increases over time. 
2. Surgical treatment: Applicable to patients with giant adenomas that show no significant improvement after more than 3 months of bromocriptine treatment, and patients desiring fertility. However, surgical treatment is often not comprehensive, and postoperative treatment with bromocriptine is usually required. 
3. Radiation therapy: Can prevent recurrence after medication discontinuation to achieve long-term control. 
4. Management of prolactinomas during pregnancy: 
   a. The risk of prolactinomas increasing in size during pregnancy is very small. 
   b. Bromocriptine should be discontinued immediately upon conception. 
   c. In cases where the tumor is >10mm, a visual field check should be performed every 4-6 weeks. If headaches or a reduction in the visual field occurs, induction of labor might be needed. If postponement of delivery is necessary, bromocriptine should be continued to reduce the tumor size. 
   d. Bromocriptine should generally be discontinued 24 hours postpartum. Breastfeeding is not recommended. 
   e. Patients using bromocriptine in the postpartum period should be aware of the effects of contraceptives. If contraception is needed, estrogen-based contraceptives should be avoided.

Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, presenting with pale yellow pubic hair, vulva and labia majora skin turning milky white or pink, while the labia minora and vaginal mucosa appear bright red.
Treatment:
What are the treatment options for Vulvar Lichen Sclerosus? What are the considerations before treatment? 

Prevention: Avoiding consanguineous marriage is crucial. Protection against OCA is important, including wearing protective eyewear. 

Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) Treatment: 

Vulvar white lesion disease, also known as chronic vulvar malnutrition, refers to a group of diseases caused by nutritional disorders in the skin and mucosa of the female genitalia, leading to tissue degeneration and pigment changes. The disease is often related to neurovascular nutritional imbalance in the deep connective tissue of the vulva, causing pathological changes in the overlying skin. 

TCM categorizes the disease based on its pathological characteristics and clinical symptoms, treating it as "vaginal itching" or "vaginal sores" determined by conditions such as itching with wind or sores with damp-heat. The disease is common in women of reproductive and older age, and rare in young girls. 

Generally, there are two types: 1) Hypertrophic malnutrition, characterized by unbearable itching of the vulva, pain after scratching, affecting the labia majora and the groove between the labia, usually symmetrical, with thickened skin resembling leather, raised with wrinkles, generally without atrophy and adhesion. 

2) Sclerotic lichenoid malnutrition, characterized by itchy lesions, whitening and thinning of the skin or mucosa, which becomes dry and easily cracked, losing elasticity, often with clitoral atrophy. Difficulties in sexual intercourse may occur in the late stage. 

Diagnosis should exclude external pruritus caused by diabetes, fungi, etc. Consider pathological examination when there are ulcers and significant hyperplasia to prevent malignant transformation. Overall assessment includes body weight, strength, sensation of cold, heat, alternating chills and fever, cold limbs. Examination of the tongue, identification of the tongue coat, pulse reading, detailed inquiry into menstruation, vaginal discharge, pregnancy, childbirth, and if siblings have the disease. 

Locally, inspect the lesion for cracks, atrophy, ulcers, hardening, adhesion, swelling, exudation, desquamation, reduced elasticity. Check if the edges of the skin lesions are neat and the boundaries clear. Observe the rash's morphology to differentiate between damp-cold, heat accumulation, yang deficiency, phlegm stasis, qi-blood deficiency, and to assess the disease's progression. Vulvar white lesions are closely related to the liver and kidney meridians, according to "Nei Jing" stating "the kidney opens up to the two yins" and "the liver meridian connects to the genitals." The main causes and mechanisms of vulvar white lesions include deficiency in kidney essence and liver blood, leading to a lack of nourishment to the vulva, coupled with attacks by external pathological wind or damp-heat stagnation. Although the disease manifests externally on the vulva, it is related to liver depression, spleen deficiency, kidney deficiency, disharmony of the Chong and Ren meridians, triggered by damp-cold, heat, yang deficiency, and phlegm stasis. 

Western Medicine Treatment: 

Currently, there is no effective cure. Treatments are symptomatic, including avoiding sunlight, using sunblock, regular health check-ups, and early detection and treatment of skin malignancies.

For cases caused by local scar proliferation or fascial compartment syndrome, conservative treatment options, including rest and physiotherapy, are recommended. Treatment:
The treatment of actinomycosis can be challenging. This is due to the difficulty in making an early diagnosis for certain locations of the infection, such as in the thoracic and abdominal regions or within the spinal column, which results in delayed treatment and generally poor prognosis. 

Surgical intervention is commonly employed, involving incision and drainage as well as the excision of necrotic tissue. The aim is to expose the infected site to air as much as possible. High doses of antibiotics are administered before and after the surgery, with penicillin being the drug of choice. Daily doses range from 2 to 6 million units, continuing for several months. In some cases, sulfonamides and iodides may also be used. Supportive care is provided for patients in poor general health. Radiation therapy may be used for infections in the facial and neck areas. 

Attention to oral hygiene and infection prevention is crucial. Post-extraction antibiotics, for example, play a significant role in preventing the occurrence of actinomycosis.

Treatment:
Treatment modalities for Vulvar Lichen Sclerosus include: 

1. Pharmacological treatment: Post washing the vulva with a pH4 acidulated feminine wash, treatments include topical application and local injection of ste**id medications, anaerobic bacillus treatment, and traditional Chinese medicinal treatments. 

2. Physical therapy: Microwave therapy, Carbon dioxide laser and Helium-Neon laser treatment, Bome light, high-frequency electrosurgical excision, local electric cauterization, and cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen. 

3. Surgical treatment: Simple vulvectomy and vulvectomy with skin grafting. 

4. Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) treatment utilizes a holistic approach to balance and nutrition with penetration therapy. This method is side-effect-free, focuses on specific targets with high efficacy, and contains multiple active and repairing factors. Its unique high-strength penetration can swiftly reach the lesion site within the body, causing irreversible coagulative necrosis in the affected tissue while sparing the surrounding tissues unharmed. This method does not affect future fertility, education or work, establishing an innovative clinical effect of ‘eliminating the lesion without damaging the tissues’. 

General Management Guidelines: 

Vulvar Lichen Sclerosus requires long-term treatment. The affected vulvar skin may thicken resembling leather or become thin and dry to the point of cracking, and in some cases, ulcers and hardening may occur. The vulvar skin becomes whitened, and irrespective of the presence of itching, a medical examination is advisable. Areas with thickened, coarse, elevated skin, ulcers, cracks, and hardening warrant caution; surgery may be necessary in some cases. The slow progression of vulvar lichen sclerosus has previously led to surgical excision due to the risk of malignancy, but surgery is no longer the advocated treatment. In advanced cases, the vaginal opening may contract and narrow, and the vulva can atrophy with the clitoris shrinking and surrounding tissues losing elasticity. Given the stubborn nature of Vulvar Lichen Sclerosus, patients are advised to adhere to long-term treatment and regular follow-ups, preferably every 3 to 6 months, to achieve satisfactory outcomes eventually. 

Patients typically experience persistent itching that can last from months to as long as 20 years, an incessant sensation that does not vary with seasons or time of the day, becoming unbearable. Accompanying tr**homoniasis or candida vaginitis may exacerbate the itching. Due to the unidentified cause, there is no specific treatment, but laser therapy or topical application of 2% testosterone propionate in cod liver oil ointment can be attempted. Regular hygiene and dryness, avoiding soaps or irritant substances for cleaning the vulva, and refraining from eating spicy or irritating foods are recommended. Loose clothing, frequent change of garments, and the use of soft cotton materials are advised. 

From a Traditional Chinese Medicine perspective, this condition is related to malnutrition, tissue degeneration, and pigment alterations in the female genital skin and mucosa, often linked to dysregulation of nerve and vascular nutrition in the deep connective tissue of the vulva. TCM treatment varies based on the characteristics and clinical symptoms of the condition, with strategies targeting ‘vulvar itching’ and ‘vulvar sores’. The condition, which is more prevalent among women in their reproductive and older years, with less incidence in young girls, can be effectively managed with TCM's nutritional balance and penetration therapy tailored to the individual’s condition, type, and constitution. TCM attributes vulvar itching to liver channel wind-heat or spleen deficiency harboring heat, suggesting that kidney deficiency failing to moisten the genitalia and wind pathogens entering the skin can cause itching and sores. TCM also holds that insufficient essence and blood, deficiencies in the Conception Vessel, and atrophy of the genitalia are key to the nutritional disturbances leading to this condition. Thus, TCM’s principle of balancing and nutritionally penetrating therapy aims at a comprehensive treatment covering itching relief, inflammation reduction, and skin nourishment, targeting the symptoms, the inducing factors, and fundamentally nourishing the vulva.

Symptoms: Snoring during sleep, sleepiness, irritability, headache
Treatment:
The treatment approaches for Obstructive Sleep Apnea-Hypopnea Syndrome (OSAHS) can be broadly categorized into non-surgical and surgical treatments apart from lifestyle changes like cessation of smoking and alcohol, weight loss, and dietary control. 
Non-surgical treatments include: 
1. Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy, which functions as an airway splint to prevent the passive collapse of soft tissues during inhalation and stimulates mechanoreceptors in the genioglossus muscle, thereby increasing airway tension. It can be used as a standalone therapy or in conjunction with surgical treatments, although long-term adherence can be challenging for patients. In countries like the United States, the majority of patients achieve satisfactory outcomes with CPAP, in contrast to domestic practices where surgery is often the prevalent treatment modality due to differences in awareness. 
2. Various orthotic devices. Using specialized orthotic devices during sleep to elevate the soft palate, actively or passively pull the tongue forward, and advance the mandible can enlarge the oropharynx and hypopharynx to improve breathing. This is one of the main non-surgical treatments for snoring and an important adjunct for non-surgical management of OSAHS, but it is ineffective for severe cases. 
3. Oxygen therapy and various pharmacological treatments such as neuro-respiratory stimulants are also supportive treatment options. 
Surgical treatments: 
Surgery is a fundamental approach to addressing OSAHS, aiming to alleviate and eliminate airway obstruction and prevent the collapse of the airway's soft tissues. The choice of surgical method depends on the site of airway obstruction, severity of the condition, presence of pathological obesity, and the overall health of the patient. Common surgical techniques include: 
1. Tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy, primarily for children with tonsil and adenoid hypertrophy before puberty. 
2. Nasal surgery for those with blocked nasal airways due to deviated nasal septum, nasal polyps, or hypertrophy of the turbinates, including septoplasty and removal of nasal polyps or turbinates to alleviate symptoms. 
3. Tongue reduction surgery for individuals with macroglossia, posterior displacement of the tongue, or enlarged lingual tonsils. 
4. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP), which involves removing the redundant tissue of the uvula and posterior edge of the soft palate as well as tightening and suturing the mucous membrane of the pharyngeal side walls to relieve airway obstruction at the level of the soft palate and oropharynx but not the hypopharynx. Proper patient selection is crucial for this procedure. 
5. Orthognathic surgery, which has grown increasingly sophisticated since the 1970s for treating maxillofacial deformities and is an effective method for managing OSAHS caused by jawbone deformities obstructing the oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal airways.

Symptoms: Fever, chronic cough, expectoration and hemoptysis, stomach pain, diarrhea, oral mucosa, tongue and palate cheesy patch curd-like white pseudomembrane, erythematous base with a burning sensation in the pharynx and larynx and at their junction, skin erythema and exudation, skin fold candidiasis, tumoral nodular, granuloma, itching, edema, erythema, epithelial peeling, and scabbing
Treatment:
Treatment options for actinomycosis include: 

1. Iodides: Iodides are effective for bronchial, pulmonary, and cutaneous actinomycosis. The usual dosage is 6g daily, often continued for 4 to 6 months. The method of administration involves dissolving 20g of potassium iodide in 300ml of water, making each 15ml of the solution contain 1g of potassium iodide. This medication is generally tolerable, with gastritis being the main side effect, which can be prevented by taking with milk or orange juice. If needed, daily intramuscular or intravenous injections of 1 to 2g of potassium iodide can be administered. Other side effects include rash, nodular erythema, and hyperthyroidism. For immunocompromised patients, azole drugs such as itraconazole or ketoconazole are recommended. 

2. Amphotericin B: This polyene antibiotic is very effective against Candida albicans and Actinomyces. For pulmonary and bronchial actinomycosis, inhale 1.5 million units of amphotericin B in polyethylene glycol as a mist. It is recommended to use the inhalation in the evening; for gastrointestinal and oral actinomycosis, amphotericin B can be taken orally or applied topically. 

3. Gentian violet: 30mg capsules of gentian violet, each coated with ethylsuccinate, can be used daily, with three capsules a day. For oral and cutaneous actinomycosis, a 0.1% gentian violet solution in 15% ethanol can be applied externally 2 to 3 times a day. 

4. Azole drugs: Suitable for pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and cutaneous actinomycosis. Ketoconazole is administered at a dose of 400mg daily, and itraconazole is used in a dosage range of 100 to 400mg daily; they can also be used in conjunction with amphotericin B or potassium iodide. 

5. Aluminum acetate solution: A 5% solution of aluminum acetate can be used to wash the external ear canal for otic actinomycosis. Afterwards, amphotericin B or clotrimazole should be applied. 

6. Amphotericin B: This drug is ineffective against any form of actinomycosis.

3. The application of glucocorticoid nasal sprays is currently the best recommended treatment for allergic rhinitis. In cases of conjunctival allergic inflammation, antihistamine therapy should be added.

Symptoms: Headache, apathetic facial expression, urinary and fecal incontinence, visual impairments, decreased appetite, nausea and vomiting, muscle soreness, coma, fever, papular rash, chest pain
Treatment:
The treatment for Gnathostomiasis involves several approaches: 
1. General Treatment: Patients should rest in bed and consume a bland, easily digestible diet. Intravenous fluids may be administered as necessary to replenish vitamins, electrolytes, and glucose. Enhanced care is crucial for patients in a coma to prevent pressure ulcers and aspiration pneumonia. 
2. Symptomatic Treatment: Concurrent use of corticosteroids during etiological treatment significantly reduces adverse reactions caused by therapeutic drugs, such as severe headaches, projectile vomiting, and major epileptic seizures. Dexamethasone is commonly used, starting at 10mg/day for 3-5 days, then reduced to 5mg/day, gradually tapering off based on the therapeutic response, with a total treatment duration of 8-20 days. In cases of intracranial hypertension symptoms (restlessness, severe headache, projectile vomiting, increased blood pressure, bradycardia, unequal pupil size, slow reaction to light), timely administration of 20% Mannitol solution is necessary, dosed at 1-2 g/kg, administered intravenously. This may be repeated after 4-8 hours if necessary, to reduce intracranial pressure and prevent herniation. 
3. Etiological Treatment: Albendazole is effective against this disease. The dosage for adults is 40mg/day for 6-10 days. The dosage for children should be appropriately reduced. To mitigate potential adverse reactions during treatment, some advocate starting with 200 mg/day for 3-5 days, then increasing to 400mg/day for an additional 5-7 days, with a total treatment duration of 10 days. Animal studies have shown that treatment with Flubendazole or Parbendazole can also be effective. However, treatments with Thiabendazole, Mebendazole, and Levamisole have been found less effective. Ivermectin, a broad-spectrum antiparasitic agent, demonstrates potent activity against a variety of nematodes, including Ascaris, Trichuris, Ancylostoma, Brugia malayi, Wuchereria bancrofti, and Onchocerca, and may also be effective against this disease. 
4. Treatment of Complications and Concomitant Disorders: Complications such as Guillain-Barre Syndrome, cerebral nerve damage, limb paralysis, and hydrocephalus may occur, as well as concurrent bacterial and fungal infections. These conditions should be addressed accordingly.
